B000002J2F|5.0|The term \\"masterpiece\\" isn't thrown around lightly by me.  So when I term Genesis 1980 effort \\"Duke\\" a masterpiece, it really doesn't get much better than this.   Many look upon \\"Duke\\" as the last hurrah in terms of Genesis being a full-fledged Progressive Rock band (I think the next effort \\"Abacab\\" still showed some Progressive Rock life left in the band).   Some will also look at \\"Duke\\" as showing some of the early signs of Genesis turning the corner into becoming a mainstream/pop band (which to some extent is fair).  Whatever the case, \\"Duke\\" scores big.    <br /> <br />When I look at Genesis as band, I see four distinct phases the band has gone through.   Phase 1 is the Peter Gabriel Era.  This spans from 1969 (\\"From Genesis to Revelation\\") to 1974 (\\"The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway\\").   It was during Phase 1 that Peter Gabriel was the lead vocalist and Genesis could easily be categorized as a progressive Rock band.   Phase 2 is the Early Phil Collins Era spanning from 1976 (\\"A Trick of the Tail\\") to 1982 (\\"Three Sides Live\\").  In this era, Phil Collins took over as lead singer.   The band was still very much a progressive rock band, but as the progressive rock landscape would change - so would Genesis.  This might indirectly have led to Phase 3 which is the Late Phil Collins Era from 1983 (\\"Genesis\\") to 1993 (\\"The Way We Walk Volume 2: The Longs\\").   This is the commercial/pop era that I referred to earlier.  At this point, there would be a lot less progressive rock flavor to Genesis' music.   The fourth phase, Phase 4 is the Ray Wilson Era.  This was when Ray Wilson took over as lead vocalist for Phil Collins.   There would only be one album in this era - 1997's  \\"Calling All Stations\\" and it seemed like Genesis tried to recapture some of their progressive rock roots - but 90s style.  \\"Duke\\" was basically done toward the end of Phase 2.  <br /> <br />In terms of being a Progressive Rock album, \\"Duke\\" clearly falls into this category.  The nice thing about \\"Duke\\"is that while it does stick to the Progressive Rock roots, it has the type of sound that will appeal to the mainstream fan.  Throw in three songs that would be classified mainstream (\\"Please Don't Ask\\", \\"Misunderstanding\\" and \\"Turn It On Again\\") and it solidifies this broad appeal.   In keeping with the times (1980), it seems as though Genesis strives to wrap this up into a \\"Concept\\" type album.   The \\"Concept\\" isn't quite tangible, but many of the songs seem to have an interwoven thread.   Using my imagination, I take the album to be a musical journey by someone named \\"Duke\\".   <br /> <br />Another interesting thing is that 5 songs are credited as being written by the combination of Tony Banks, Mike Rutherford, and Phil Collins.  However the remaining seven songs are credited as being written individually by Tony Banks (who has 3), Mike Rutherford (who has 2), and Phil Collins (who has 2).  You can see that Phil has the most \\"Pop\\" influence with the songs \\"Misunderstanding\\" and the ballad \\"Please Don't Ask\\".   I think Tony has the most Progressive Rock sounding songs (\\"Guide Vocal\\", \\"Heathaze\\", and \\"Cul De Sac\\").   Mike straddles between the fence of Progressive (\\"Man Of Our Times\\") and quasi-Pop (\\"Alone Tonight\\"). <br /> <br />The collection starts off with a four song \\"suite\\".  These are basically four songs that segue one into another.   The suite starts off with \\"Behind the Lines\\".  This is a song that Phil Collins would also cover on his \\"Face Value\\" solo album.  This is a jointly written song by the trio and really kicks off the \\"musical journey\\".  I think Collins' drums are incredible on this song.   The song then eases into what is the suite and the collection's most powerful track - \\"Duchess\\".  The music slows down and then builds back up over 2 minutes into some powerful and emotional music.  You can hear the raw emotion in Phil's voice and Tony's keyboard playing.  \\"Duchess\\", which seems to be the story of a female performer named \\"Duchess\\" was anothertrack written by the trio.   \\"Duchess\\" progresses nicely into the third song of the suite which is Tony's (written) \\"Guide Vocal\\".  This is a short and soft song 1:30+ minute song which is the perfect interlude to Mike's (written) \\"Man of All Seasons\\".   On this track the trio has their \\"A\\" game with Phil's percussion, Tony's keyboards and Mike's guitars.  This is a nice wrap up to almost 20 minutes of non-stop music. <br /> <br />When I first got \\"Duke\\", I got it on LP.  I always considered the second side of \\"Duke\\" (last 6 songs on the CD) one of the greatest album sides of all time.  Sure \\"Turn It On Again\\" is a classic, but all the songs contributed. One very powerful song is Tony's (written) \\"Cul De Sac\\".   This is a classic Progressive Rock tune.  The set wraps up with another segue of \\"Duke's Travels\\" and \\"Duke's End\\".  \\"Duke's Travels is almost a full instrumental.  No lyrics are listed for this song in the liner notes, but about 6+ minutes into the song, Phil will sing.  \\"Duke's End\\" is a perfect wrap-up as it incorparates sounds from \\"Behind the Lines\\" and \\"Turn It On Again\\".   \\"Alone Tonight\\" was a song that sat perfectly between \\"Turn It On Again\\" and \\"Cul De Sac\\" while \\"Please Don't Ask\\" is the perfect song between \\"Cul De Sac\\" and \\"Duke's Travels\\". <br /> <br />The CD has illustrations that kind of remind you like a children's storybook.   This illustrations carry over into the liner notes and there is a different illustration on each page. The font of the lyrics also is kind of like storybook font.  All of the lyrics (with the exception of \\"Duke's Travels\\") are included along with the appropriate songwriting credits.   This is a great album and will appeal to old and new Genesis fans. I highly recommend this \\"masterpiece\\" to add your collection.

B000001FA4|5.0|The 1985 release of \\"Unforgettable Fire\\" vaulted U2 into heavy video rotation and arena rock. With the production team of Brian Eno/Daniel Lanois at the helm, the group's sound shaped with new keyboard textures and lots of layering of The Edge's guitars. Some might say the disk was over-produced. We also get Bono's trademark emotive breathing on several tracks.<br /><br />I wavered between giving this 4 or 5 stars, so 4.5 might be the best assessment. The primary reason most people got this album was for the mega-popular anthem \\"Pride (In the Name of Love)\\" with its Christ imagery (\\"one man betrayed with a kiss...\\") and Martin Luther King, Jr. theme (\\"early morning, April 4, shot rings out...\\") and memorable guitar melody. One of my all-time favorites is \\"A Sort of Homecoming\\" and I especially like the lyric \\"faces ploughed like fields that once gave no resistance.\\" There's a strong Ireland theme here, and this is a great leadoff song. One drawback is that I think the mix is a little muddy.<br /><br />\\"Wire\\" is a high energy piece with a chunky bassline, great drums, and very cool guitars.<br /><br />\\"The Unforgettable Fire\\" really brings out the guitar atmospherics, along with a string section, and another powerful vocal from Bono.<br /><br />\\"Promenade\\" is not a bad song, but it's really a sound-alike to many of the other songs, and not a particularly memorable memory.<br /><br />\\"4th of July\\" is a sonic instrumental introduction to \\"Bad\\", which is one of the best songs on the disk. Great simple guitar melody and vocal performance with the \\"I'm wide awake...and I'm sleeping\\" rise and fall dynamics. Perhaps some of Adam Clayton's best bass work to this point. Check this song out on the \\"Wide Awake in America\\" live EP. It's a beautiful tune.<br /><br />\\"Indian Summer Sky\\" is like \\"Promenade\\" in that it's not a bad song, but not as good as its sound-alike, \\"Wire.\\"<br /><br />\\"Elvis Presley and America\\" shows U2's growing love affair with Americana. It's a nice ballad.<br /><br />\\"MLK\\" is the true Martin Luther King, Jr. tribute, a gospel-like vocal over some light keyboard textures. It's a great under-stated performance by Bono and nice closer for the disk.<br /><br />The strengths by far lift up the few weaker tunes, and this disk is very listenable in its entirety.as its sound-alike, \\"Wire.\\" <br />\\"Elvis Presley and America\\" shows U2's growing love affair with Americana. B00028HBKC|1.0|THE PASSION <br /> <br />0 Stars! <br /> <br />The Amazon synopsis is typical PR for this sadly, fearful and ugly film: Salute Mel Gibson for his bravery and integrity in putting his own cash and career on the line for his beliefs. It's fine to admire a determined director. Unfortunately, it's not a valid review of his film. <br /> <br />Despite the many objections to the Passion's sado-masochistic heavy-handedness, what is most reprehensible about the film is Gibson & Company's insistence on the reality - indeed, the divine nature - of its creation. However, there is very little biblical textual reality to Gibson's rendition, certainly very little of what we Catholics and Christians call \\"The Word.\\"  <br /> <br />The screenplay - by Gibson and Benedict Fitzgerald - takes rash liberties with all New Testament texts and adds its own sound bite relish. Much is owed to contemporary interpretation. Throughout, Jesus insists on his own divinity. Throughout, Mary is the dutiful mother figure cleaning up after her son, the Apostles are speechless weaklings, the Pharisees conniving Shylocks, the Romans giddy sadists. And throughout, an androgynous devil figure watches on with B-movie eyes of glee. No wonder Gibson did not originally want his film sullied with sub-titles - he didn't want his audience to see the obvious chinks in the armor of his allegedly \\"historically accurate\\" creation. <br /> <br />He needn't have feared. Contrary to the tidal wave of pre-opening press declaring its uniqueness (it's subititled!), the film panders to contemporary society's adolescent worship and glorification of violence - and, therefore, fits right in with today's Hollywood historical offerings such as Gibson's \\"Braveheart\\" and Russell Crowe's \\"Gladiator.\\" The abhorrent violence - again, so briefly sketched in the Gospels - is here relentless, splashed across the screen in slow motion, stop-time, close-up \\"Braveheart\\" lengths. Jesus is flogged like a tenderized sirloin. His pierced side produces a fountain that waters the crowd. (I checked my Home Medical Manual to verify that, indeed, human beings only have 10 pints of blood to spill). It's voyeurism at its absolute worst. <br /> <br />Finally, the saddest impression one takes from Gibson's film is that Jesus was tortured and died. Is that why his impact on mankind has been so great? There is little allusion to His teachings - a few token flashbacks of Jesus \\"on message\\" with his followers - but these moments lack any charismatic significance or volition to the story's plot. What finally resonates in Gibson's \\"The Passion of the Christ\\" is the fear and cruelty of man. And that's exactly what Jesus' life so beautifully transcended.  <br /> <br />You would never know that by viewing this film. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

When it finally came out in stores, i of course bought it the first day it came out. i actually MET them on the day it came out so that was really really awesome.(the guys are awesome, especially DAVID.) but anyways, once i listened to the damn cd, i was automatically HOOKED and IN LOVE with. i think the cd is an AWESOME new album and they couldnt have done it better. every song i hear, i can relate to and the sound of the album is really really good. i honestly think that this album is better then their debut. i think their debut album included more quantity then quality. but in their new album, it was more quality than quanity, which to my opinion isnt actually a bad thing. so what im trying to say is, Simple Plan's sophomore album is BEYOND AMAZING. this disc is definitely gonna stay in my cd player for a loooong time. =)

B00005Q4CS|3.0|...only in slow-motion, with lots of MTV-ish intercutting, speeded-up sequences, and a pulsating soundtrack as the carnage unfolds and the blood splatters the lens.<br /><br />Only here the carnage is not only physical but more unbearably, psychological, emotional, spiritual, and sexual.  In a nutshell: onrushing catastrophes at every level.<br /><br />This is one of those films, in the tradition of \\"Breaking the Waves,\\" where during the first 10 minutes you see very clearly that the main characters---quite sympathetic, unfortunately---are going to be on a fast-accelerating downhill slide for the rest of the movie.  Unlike similar films that chronicle a steady process of chemical-related self-destruction (\\"Trainspotting\\" and \\"Leaving Las Vegas\\" come to mind), \\"Requiem for a Dream\\" will never be accused of \\"glamorizing\\" or \\"romanticizing\\" substance abuse.  Director Aranofsky seems to take special pains to capture every excruciating torture and suffering that his protagonists undergo---in fact, he even uses film and sound techniques to amplify it and shove our noses into it.<br /><br />Unfortunately, while the film is fairly bold as art, and probably quite accurate as social documentary, as an aesthetic work it simply is not very enjoyable to watch.  Both \\"Trainspotting\\" and \\"Leaving Las Vegas\\" had similarly bleak and hopeless storylines, yet managed to tell those stories in creative and interesting ways, rather than just straight-up, visually-enhanced journalistic docudrama...i.e. both were far more enjoyable because they were much more multi-dimensional, their characters were far better developed and far less predictable.  Leto, Connelly, Wayans, and Burstyn are all talented actors and appealing characters but they are barely developed beyond the black holes of their addictions and compulsions; instead they are presented as basically 4 hopeless and helpless lambs about to be tortured and eaten alive before our eyes in myriad ways.<br /><br />About the only truly original and insightful character drama is that played by Ellen Burstyn, in that we are all too rarely shown the more mainstream addictions that is sadly predominant in American society: food, television, and prescription (diet, in this case) meds.  She was the most interesting of the bunch by far, the other 3 leads are all cardboard characters we've seen a million times before, albeit played by very competent actors.<br /><br />This film could've been far more original, interesting, and insightful if it had simply focused on Burnstyn's character as a case study for mainstream America---lobotomized by TV, living isolated miserable lives in a dysfunctional community and culture, bloated by junk food used as pleasure substitutes, getting their fixes from the local pharmacy.<br /><br />Three stars for visual/aural stimulation but shallow and cliched storyline.ly truly original and insightful character drama is that played by Ellen Burstyn, in that we are all too rarely shown the more mainstream addictions that is sadly predominant in American society: food, television, and prescription (diet, in this case) meds. B00000G3AZ|4.0|First I would like to start with the positive aspects of this version of \\"Emma\\".  The casting was almost 100% perfect. Emma may be misguided, but she is good-hearted.  That is how Paltrow played her. <br /> <br />I really enjoyed Northam's portrayal of Knightley.  His thoughtfulness and kindness were expressed well.  His insight into the other characters was displayed.  However, the best aspect was the friendly interplay between Paltrow and Knightley.  They are believable as friends and as lovers. Their future marriage will be a happy one because not only are they attracted to one another; they truly esteem one another. <br /> <br />Juliet Stevenson was WONDERFUL as Mrs. Elton.  Shallow, snide and jealous she was.  I loved to hate her!  Delicious! <br /> <br />The lovely Greta Scacchi played my ideal of Mrs. Weston. In those times, a woman needed to pretty, demure and married.  Poor Miss Bates is none of those things.  She feels herself to be a failure in life.  She is a social person by nature, but society denigrates her.  She is despised by the thing she loves.  Thompson played this very well. <br /> <br />Now for what I didn't agree with in the movie.  I'm sorry, but Harriet Smith was not portrayed accurately in this film version.  This was no fault of actress Colette.  The fault is in direction and script.  Harriet was a simpleton, yes, but she was sweet-natured and quite pretty.  Austen brings this out again and again.  After all, Emma thought that it was possible for her to marry Elton, Churchill and Knightley.  No one would have believed it possible in this Harriet Smith.  Robert Martin would not have married her either. <br /> <br />I also did not care for Polly Walker's version of Jane Fairfax.  Jane is a reserved person in extremely difficult circumstances, living in cramped conditions, facing an uncertain future, in love with man not her equal.  Walker simply played her like an untouchable goddess.  True, that is how Emma sees her at first; that is why she is jealous of her, but that is not how Jane really is.  Jane has feelings and is actually a romantic at heart.  Jane is frustrated and for that suffers headaches and ill health, like we all do when faced with prolonged stress.  That is how I think she should have been played.   <br /> <br />However, that does not mean I didn't like the movie.  I did.  I also liked \\"Jane Austen's Emma\\", but for different reasons.  Really, everyone must do themselves a favor and see them both!
6304696566|5.0|I have read many of the nearby reviews and nothing has been missed, the symbolism and all.  What I may be able to add is before this was available I recorded it off cable TV and pulled it out often to watch.  It is a great shame that this movie was not taken seriously when it first came out; the Duke rarely gave such an intense performance as he does here.  But Westerns were a dime a dozen and dismissed as kiddie fare despite the advent of the first \\"adult\\" Western \\"High Noon\\" 4 years earlier.  The photography is fantasatic, the performances are first rate and the dialogue, well, is mostly good.  Vera Miles (also in Wayne's \\"The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance\\") plays the spinster patiently waiting for Ethan Edwards (Wayne) and her awkward-in-love beau (Jeffrey Hunter) to return from the search for the kidnapped girl while Ken Curtis (\\"Festus\\" of TV's \\"Gunsmoke\\" and former member of Sons of the Pioneers) romances her with his guitar.  Panhandle Pete Perkins, a Western veteran, is a dotty oldtimer.  Wayne perennial Ward Bond is on hand as a preacher and lawman/military man whose \\"authority\\" does not impress Wayne's character.  Patrick (Dad--got-me-the-job) Wayne turns in a good performance as a green cavalry man.  Harry Carey, Jr. is on hand in the search until a fit of rage drives him into the gunfire of the outlaw Indians.  Wayne pays tribute to Carey's father, a cowboy star in Hollywood's early days, in the end by resting his elbow in his hand (a Carey, Sr. trademark gesture) before turning his back on the warm family scene that he has made possible but is somehow foreign to him and wanders rather aimlessly away.  Oscar worthy.  You can get this flick in a set with other great Wayne movies if you like, but don't miss having THIS one.  Incidentally, early rocker Buddy Holly took the line that Ethan often spouts in the movie \\"that'll be the day\\" and made it into his successful rock song the following year. All good things.

1401301010|4.0|This was a deeply personal autobiography that dealt with all the highs and lows that Hollywood has to offer. Anthony chose to divulge more about himself and his inner demons, rather than right a tell-all about his band mates. A lot of this book deals with the relationship he had with his father when he was a young boy, and had chose to move to Hollywood, over a life in the mid-west with his mother, and what a profound effect it had on his life. He deals with struggling to have some assemblance of a normal life with his father (aka, \\"The Lord of the Sunset Strip\\"), while living in the midst of drug infestation, and just total debauchery as a kid. In the midst of so much chaos for someone so young he met Flea and Hillel, and started a band with them, that would improve his life financially, and in other ways make it worse.  It makes you really feel for him, and come to understand how someone coming from such an unstable background could come up with such deep and moving lyrics. He goes through a stream of beautiful women who offered him support through his addictions, only to kick them all to the curb. It makes you wonder if he could work to make a commitment to any one of these women if he would have more stablility in his life, rather than constantly seeking approval of the men around him as his support. It is inspiring to see someone who has been through so much, and be able to keep on. With everything he has been through, and his optimism seemingly on the rise, it does feel there are still a lot of resources left for plenty of new songwriting.

This film almost makes you pause when you receive an unsolicited phone call from a salesman.  Let me emphasize, almost.
0440238609|5.0|I have always loved these books and would reccommend them to readers of all ages for not only the depth of plot but the masterful writing as well.   <br /> <br />This just in, though... \\"His dark materials\\" may be an allusion to Milton's Paradise Lost.  Check it out! <br /> <br />In Book II, Milton is describing the panorama of Hell as Satan looks upon it for the first time, and says,  <br />\\"Into this wild Abyss,/ the Womb of nature and perhaps her Grave,/ of neither Sea, nor Shore, nor Air, nor Fire,/ But all these in their pregnant causes mixt/ Confus'dly, and which thus must ever fight,/ Unless th'Almighty Maker them ordain/ His dark materials to create more Worlds,/ Into this wild Abyss the wary fiend/ Stood on the brink of Hell and look'd a while,/ Pondering his voyage...\\" (Lines 910-919).   <br /> <br />This seems to be essentially saying that there will be unbalance, disorder, and chaos in the world (\\"causes mixt confus'dly, and which thus must ever fight\\") unless God --- or perhaps some other sentient, omnipotent being, if we were to venture outside the Judeo-Christian tradition --- were to use \\"His dark materials\\" to create new worlds in which all problems were solved. <br /> <br />So... considering that quotation in the context of Philip Pullman's \\"His Dark Materials\\" trilogy, the books are even more impressive, not to mention thought-provoking. <br /> <br />Interesting.

B00028HBKM|1.0|This film is melodramatic garbage, and I must wonder why more Christian folks weren't up in arms over the film. Apart from the beautiful languages spoken throughout the course of the film, there's very little in terms of merit here. I understand the point intended by displaying the slow physical death of Jesus is to make us feel compassion, but the flaying and beating go on for so long as to desensitize the viewer to the graphic violence. Instead of emotion or depth, we're treated to lots of make-up effects and gallons upon gallons of stage blood. Criticism that the only \\"content\\" of the film comes from the flashbacks is misguided -these scenes play out as a \\"best-of-Jesus\\" montage that do little more than alter the pace of the film. The intended point was probably to make up for the complete lack of character development or any sort of insight, but the actual function is that it breaks up long and (at least initially) unsettling scenes so that we don't grow bored as the inevitable approaches. All of the acting here is hollow, wooden fare save for the woman playing Mary. This is all further trivialized by the completely laughable stabs at frightening the viewers: demon children chasing down Judas, the withered \\"devil baby\\", and then, that most offensive sequence of all, the three-quarters-perspective pull back of Satan crying out \\"NOOOOOOO!!!!\\" from Hell, which is apparently some place comprised of badly rendered CGI by multimedia students at the corporate \\"art\\" school of your choice. As a non-Christian, I'm outraged that this film got positive reviews. I've discussed much of this with Christian friends of mine, and several opted to not see this film on my advice; the one who did phoned me after watching and agreed with me. If you believe in Jesus, or agree with some of the ideals presented in the New Testament, this film will raise hackles on your back. It's sensationalistic, Hollywood-style crap masquerading as a purportedly moving indie film. Avoid at all costs.

B0002VKZL6|5.0|Mark Knopfler's latest solo effort does not disappoint, unless you are one of the hard-core Dire Straits fan who will never be happy until Knopfler returns to hard-driving rock. (And we amazon shoppers have seen our share of those reviewers...) This album is not Dire Straits. What it is, however, is story-telling at its finest, which has always been one of Knopfler's strong points.  Knopfler is one of the best lyricists in music today, and \\"Shangri La\\" shows this nearly as well as \\"Sailing to Philadelphia,\\" which remains in my opinion the strongest of Knopfler's solo works.  I do not mean to slight the music on this album by emphasizing the lyrics, however; Knopfler will always be one of the greatest guitarists, period, with a unique style and sound that is so characteristic that I knew immediately there was a new Knopfler album out when I heard just a snippet of a song played on the local public radio station. Nobody else makes a guitar sound the way Knopfler does.<br /><br />But nobody writes songs the way Knopfler does, as well, and every one of his albums--both solo efforts and with Dire Straits--contains quiet gems that tackle topics that are rarely the subject of popular music.  Take, for example, the track \\"Boom, Like That,\\" which is, in my opinion, the best song on this album. Musically it is the catchiest of the bunch, and the one most likely to make a dent in the charts.  But it's not until you concentrate on the lyrics that you realize it is also biting social commentary, describing Ray Kroc's buyout of the McDonald's name and his chutzpah in deciding to force the brothers out of business later on by opening a McDonald's across the street from their subsequent  restaurant.  When Knopfler sings \\"It's dog eat dog/ rat eat rat/ Kroc-style, boom, like that\\" it's an indictment not just of Ray Kroc but the entire remorseless, survival-of-the-fittest nature of unfettered capitalism.<br /><br />The other highlight on the album is the title track, a prototypical soft and crooning Knopfler love song.  As you listen to its chorus, \\"This is all the heaven we've got/ right here where we are/ in our Shangri La,\\" the listener realizes that as long as there is a Mark Knopfler on earth to give us music of such depth and beauty, it's really all the heaven we need.al soft and crooning Knopfler love song.  As you listen to its chorus, \\"This is all the heaven we've got/ right here where we are/ in our Shangri La,\\" the listener realizes that as long as there is a Mark Knopfler on earth to give us music of such depth and beauty, it's really all the heaven we need.

B00008DDRX|5.0|This is the ultimate racing movie! Forget garbage like \\"Days of Thunder\\" and \\"Driven\\", this is the real deal. You can tell Steve's passion for racing in this movie. Of course once you've seen it, you'll have to read \\"A French Kiss With Death\\" which tells the tale of the making of \\"Le Mans\\" and the race itself.
B00005AQGH|5.0|If you are wondering which 2Pac albums you should buy this one should be near the top of your list.  I have all of 2Pac's albums (including sountracks & compilations) and I have to say that this album had 2Pac at his best.<br /><br />This album was released less than two months after 2Pac was killed & was recorded in seven days (hence the title \\"The 7 Day Theory\\").  This album contains twelve tracks.  Many rap fans might think this to be a small number of tracks for a rap album but 2Pac made every single track on this album to the best of his abilities.<br /><br />The first track is called Bomb First (My Second Reply) and is pretty much an unofficial part 2 to Hit Em Up.  Of course this track isn't quite as explicit as Hit Em Up but it gets it's point across well:  Death to Bad Boy Records.  This is a pretty good track but definitely not what I'd call a highlight track on this album.<br /><br />The next track is titled Hail Mary and is one of the creepiest 2Pac tracks that I have ever heard.  One of the lines 2Pac spits on this song is \\"when you turn out the lights I'll be there in the dark, thuggin eternal through my heart\\".  The way he raps this song gives me the chills every time I hear it.  This is definitely a highlight of the album!<br /><br />Track three is a track titled Toss It Up and is a party track that has K-Ci & JoJo hooking back up with 2Pac.  The funny thing about this track is that the first half is obviously about sex but on the second half of the track 2Pac starts dissing Dr. Dre.  I know that this is because Dr. Dre supposidly stole the original beat for Toss It Up and gave it to Blackstreet (it's the track titled No Diggity).  Although 2Pac's verbal assault on Dr. Dre in this song wouldn't make sense to \\"casual\\" 2Pac fans this is still a very good track and another Highlight of the album.<br /><br />Track four is one of my personal favorites.  It's To Live & Die In LA.  2Pac shows us his deep passion for LA and it's people and this track does make me wish I could see LA.  This is a fun track and is yet another champion track to this album.  At the end you'll hear yet another Dre Diss.  At the end of the track 2Pac says \\"California Love part motherf***in' 2 without [...] @$$ Dre\\".<br /><br />The next three tracks are titled Blasphemy, Life Of An Outlaw, & Just Like Daddy.  Many 2Pac fans love these tracks and while I did find them to be good they are not highlight tracks.  These are one's that I occasionally skip over.<br /><br />Track 8 is titled Krazy & is a really great 2Pac track.  It features Bad Azz & is one of the sadder songs on this album.  It's truely 2Pac speaking from the heart on this one.  This is a highlight track & one that I'm sure will show up on a 2Pac Greatest Hits part 2 CD if one ever gets created.<br /><br />White Man'z World is a track that I'm split about.  I really love the production and 2Pac's verses but the subject matter is a bit touchy.  Fans of Brenda's Got A Baby & Keep Ya Head Up will be satisfied with this track.  People who are tired of \\"blame whitey for all of your problems\\" songs will probably find this track to be one of the worst on the album.  But I feel that everyone has a right to their opinions so I'll say that while this track is good it's not a highlight track.<br /><br />Track 10 is titled Me & My Girlfriend and is a ballad of 2Pac's love for his gun.  This is a great great track and should be hailed as one of 2Pac's all time best.  This is another one that would make in on Greatest Hits part 2 album.  Excellent track!<br /><br />The last two tracks of this album are titled Hold Ya Head & Against All Odds.  Hold Ya Head is a pretty good track that holds it own on this album.  It's a song done in the same style as Brenda's Got a Baby or Keep Ya Head Up.  Against All Odds is a great ruthless track.  2Pac names names of specifically who he thinks shot him back in 1994 on this track.  It's a hard track that will make you want to ride.<br /><br />Overall this is a great album.  This album along with All Eyez On Me & Me Against The World is one of 2Pac's best albums.  This is one that should not be missed.<br /><br />P.S.  Hardcore 2Pac fans should know that the new 2Pac Album tentatively titled Loyal 2 The Game will be hitting stores by December of 2004!  Eminem served as Co-Executive Producer on this album so those of you who liked the tracks he produced on the Tupac: Resurrection Soundtrack are in for a treat!s best albums.  This is one that should not be missed.    P.S.  Hardcore 2Pac fans should know that the new 2Pac Album tentatively titled Loyal 2 The Game will be hitting stores by December of 2004!  Eminem served as Co-Executive Producer on this album so those of you who liked the tracks he produced on the Tupac: Resurrection Soundtrack are in for a treat!
B0000TLA9G|4.0|This is a genuinely exciting album of 14 well-known Guns 'N Roses tracks from the band's glory years of 1987-93. November Rain is the best-ever epic rock ballad of its type - magnificent electric guitar work and grand strings. Breakthrough track Sweet Child O' Mine still sounds good today. Their covers of Live And Let Die and Sympathy For The Devil are also good, while hard-edged rock music like 1991 hit You Could Be Mine showed how powerful this band was. I like the way they were able to do slow, acoustic stuff too (like Patience), which showed that they were good musicians. I was pumped up after playing my new copy of this scorching Greatest Hits set recently - an effect which a lot of lesser rock bands don't achieve with their music.  <br /> <br />4 stars from me.

0064407667|5.0|I wish some of the lower-star reviewers would stop analyzing this series so much and stop complaining about the violence and how bad all the adults in the story are. First of all, in some books written for children, many times some of the adult characters are written as either really stupid or else very mean or evil. The Harry Potter books are a prime example.  Both the Harry Potter series and the Lemony Snickett series are tales of good versus evil. Oftentimes there is an exaggeration of the bad characters. It just makes for a more interesting story.  I found The Bad Beginning to be fascinating and captivating from the first chapter. I can't wait to read the next book and all the ones after that. I'm hooked on the series and will be seeing the movie for sure.  I'm glad this is yet another series of books that will lure in kids of all ages, and like the Harry Potter books, will instill  young readers with an interest in reading.I liked how the Lemony Snicket books are short and very fast-paced. There was not a boring moment in the book. Wish i could say the same for Harry Potter And The Goblet Of Fire, which i found tedious as hell to read.  I read  the whole first Lemony book in under a few hours and i liked the author's literary style and his technique of explaining the meaning of some of the vocabulary words as the story goes along. This alone, will increase a young-person's vocabulary. Though they may not use those particular words in everyday conversation, when they see them again in print sometime in the future, they will know the meanings. I think this series of books will be as popular as Harry Potter, and in some ways even more so. Highly recommended. As for the  violence in the book, some of it may be a bit scary for very young children under 9, but any child who has watched today's tv shows won't be bothered by what happens in the story. If anything, it just heightens the events and makes it all more fascinating and fun. And anyway, if you're bothered with your kids reading this series, there IS a warning from Lemony Snicket himself that this story is not happy at all and doesn't have a happy ending.h your kids reading this series, there IS a warning from Lemony Snicket himself that this story is not happy at all and doesn't have a happy ending.
B000000WG3|5.0|In 1985, Gary went back to Ireland and played(for the first time since his teenage years) in Belfast. On Wild Frontier, his first studio album after that trip, Gary revisits his homeland in songs. This album was clearly born from his trip back home as many of the songs are about Ireland and even the music itself is steeped in his celtic roots. <br />The title track was originally intended to be sung by Phil Lynott(who also sang on two tracks on Gary's previous album, Run For Cover) but his untimely passing prevented that. The album itself is dedicated to Phil's memory and I think he would have loved the musical stories that are contained here. <br /> <br />The songs Over The Hills And Far Away and Thunder Rising are as much short stories as they are songs. They are stories of Ireland present(Over The Hills) and past(Thunder). The title track is a beautiful song obviously born from his love of his homeland. The Loner is an outstanding instrumental that really showcases Gary's style of play. <br />The guitar playing this album is incredible. It is passionate and, at times, understated. It is also worth noting that Gary has rarely sounded as at home on the vocals as he does here. I think this albums shows his maturity as a singer as well as a guitarist. <br />Wild Frontier is an essential Gary Moore album that should be in the collection of any fan of his.

B000093OU8|5.0|In 1985, Gary went back to Ireland and played(for the first time since his teenage years) in Belfast. On Wild Frontier, his first studio album after that trip, Gary revisits his homeland in songs. This album was clearly born from his trip back home as many of the songs are about Ireland and even the music itself is steeped in his celtic roots. <br /> The title track was originally intended to be sung by Phil Lynott(who also sang on two tracks on Gary's previous album, Run For Cover) but his untimely passing prevented that. The album itself is dedicated to Phil's memory and I think he would have loved the musical stories that are contained here. <br /> The songs Over The Hills And Far Away and Thunder Rising are as much short stories as they are songs. They are stories of Ireland present(Over The Hills) and past(Thunder). The title track is a beautiful song obviously born from his love of his homeland. The Loner is an outstanding instrumental that really showcases Gary's style of play.  <br /> Added to this rerelease are the 12'' version of Friday On My Mind,an extended version of the Loner that was originally available on a limited Edition double lp version of Wild Frontier,as well as a live version of Out In The fields. Both versions of the cd feature the 12\\" versions of Wild Frontier and Over The Hills And Far Away. <br /> The guitar playing this album is incredible. It is passionate and, at times, understated. It is also worth noting that Gary has rarely sounded as at home on the vocals as he does here. I think this albums shows his maturity as a singer as well as a guitarist. <br /> Wild Frontier is an essential Gary Moore album that should be in the collection of any fan of his. This rerelease, with the bonus tracks, is superior to the original and must be recomended over the previous version.

B000244FDW|5.0|I have longed for this to be available on DVD and was afraid that the A & E version would preclude this re-release. Happily, given the bargain rate, Austen fans can enjoy both versions. While I must say I adore Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy, I really prefer the rest of this cast to that of the A & E editon. Elizabeth Garvie IS Elizabeth Bennett to me; the other actress playing EB was too \\"modern.\\" (In fact, she reminded me of a flapper that landed in the wrong period piece; too much smirking and not enough wit for Our Miss Bennett.) And Lady Catherine deBurghe--this actress really makes her terribly believable (and therefore, Eliza much more courageous for standing up to her), whereas in the A & E version she's a frail old lady one feels rather sorry for (and therefore Eliza gains no points for taking her down a peg or two). I wish we had a computer technology to put this cast into the lush historic settings of the A & E version, but barring that, buy both!

This was not the era of Slayer, Megadeth or Metallica. It was also before \\"new-wave\\" as you called them.  Also Rush was an influence of Metallica's, especially with Cliff. <br /> <br />\\"Proud Led Head\\" I love Zep too. Rush was a \\"Progressive Rock\\" band with more of technical musical background with some influences from Zeppelin.  Both very talented bands, just very different styles.  <br /> <br />Lastly, \\"J. McAndrew\\" your drug comments baffle me.  You site that \\"all the kids who were doing well\\" were listening to jazz, and Rush fans are all \\"drug heads.\\" I'll admit that in the 70's there was a lot of drug use going on, everyone was doing it.... Drugs have been in jazz since the beginning of the jazz area.  Cab Calloway sang about the \\"Reefer man\\", even Satchmo smoked marijuana.  There are many more references, too many to list here. <br /> <br />Well I'm sure that you are sick of reading this by now,  that is if you are still reading... B0006284JQ|5.0|Whether you love her or hate her, idolize her or resent her, it is undeniable that Miss Britney Spears has made an enormous impact in pop culture-and our society in general (whether that impact be negative or positive is arguable). Anyways, some say it's too early, but I think Britney has more than enough hits to release a Best Of album. I just want to make one thing clear: I really, REALLY do not like Britney Spears as a person. I have lost all respect for her. But you know what? Yes, as much as it may make some of you cringe, I buy music for catchy beats, danceable tunes, and just....enjoyable music. I don't like Britney Spears, I think her image is going down the toilet, and I'm not impressed with her voice. But her music is catchy and infectious as hell-a succulent guilty pleasure. Anyways, here's a review of each song:  <br /> <br />MY PREROGATIVE- This song really, REALLY rubbed me the wrong way the first time I heard it. Like \\"Slave\\" and \\"Boys,\\" it is crackling electrofunk that doesn't suit Britney. And yet...lately, it's starting to grow on me. You have to listen to it a few times. Believe it or not, though, it is far poppier than the original, proving that Britney is staying true to her bubblegum roots to the very end. The chorus will likely get stuck in your head-whether you like it or not. A nice song to sing along to when you're pissed off. (3/5)   <br /> <br />TOXIC- In my personal opinion, this is her best song of all time. The beat is infectious, the chorus is insanely catchy, and the background effects are awesome. Such a cool song. I'm getting a *tad* tired of it because I've heard it a few too many times, but when you hear it for the first time it's mind-blowing. I know a lot of Britney-haters who love this. (5/5)  <br /> <br />I'M A SLAVE 4 U- I've always thought this one was a tad overrated, but nice, funky little club beat. It's a bit boring. The beginning sounds raw. But once the chorus gets going, it's kind of cool. (4/5)  <br /> <br />OOPS!...I DID IT AGAIN- Ah, a delicious teen pop pleasure. Very catchy chorus, background effects that are easy on the ears and yet danceable and catchy. (5/5)  <br /> <br />ME AGAINST THE MUSIC- Like this one, but don't really adore it. It's pretty cool-very, very unique. Unlike anything she's ever done. A good street/club track. (4/5)  <br /> <br />STRONGER- I think this is her second-best song of all time. Love the chorus. I sort of like the lyrics, too-her only independent song. But all of her lyrics are airy in some form or way. Anyways, great song to dance to. (5/5)  <br /> <br />EVERYTIME- This is the only ballad by her that I truly enjoy. Sweet piano melody. A sad song, I suppose, but it's really hard to take any of her 'emotions' seriously. But a masterfully crafted ballad tune, nonetheless. (5/5) <br /> <br />...BABY ONE MORE TIME- This is THE Britney Spears song. This song MADE her and put her where she is today. But I don't think this is her best song. Far from it, in fact. Quite catchy, though. But I think I've heard it a few too many times. It's getting old. (4/5) <br /> <br />(YOU DRIVE ME) CRAZY [THE STOP REMIX!]- The original version of \\"Crazy\\" was somewhat catchy, but nothing incredibly special. It sounded a bit dull and raw. The Stop! Remix, on the other hand, is downright explosive and in my opinion is better than \\"...Baby One More Time.\\" The beat is far more hard-hitting, and it motivates you to get up and dance far sooner than the original. (5/5)  <br /> <br />BOYS [CO-ED REMIX] FEATURING PHARRELL WILLIAMS- Basically, a rip of of Janet Jackson's \\"Nasty\\" and Britney's own \\"I'm A Slave 4 U.\\" This song is nothing special. And this Pharrell guy can't sing at all. Britney puts him to shame vocally, and that is just sad. The remix is better than the original, but this still....really isn't very good. (2/5)  <br /> <br />SOMETIMES- I've really never liked this song. Goes beyond bubblegum and leans more towards childish. She doesn't have the voice for ballads. She shouldn't do them. (1/5)  <br /> <br />OVERPROTECTED-THE DARKCHILD REMIX [RADIO EDIT]- \\"Overprotected\\" is an awesome song-one of my favorites by Britney. This remix, however, is massively overrated. I don't think it's better than the original. They should have included the original version. The backing track is too repetitive. But the undeniably catchy beat shines through. (3/5)  <br /> <br />LUCKY- For some reason, I was just fascinated by this song when it first came out. But now that I have the whole thing on a CD, it's nothing spectacular. However, the beat is quite catchy and I still like it. An old-fashioned beat. The third-best song on her second album. (5/5)  <br /> <br />OUTRAGEOUS- This was never a hit. They tried to make a video out of it (and I don't know why, because In The Zone has way better to offer), but as I'm *SURE* you all know, she injured herself in the process. A tad repetitive. I love the breakdown in the middle, I have to admit. (4/5)      <br /> <br />I'M NOT A GIRL, NOT YET A WOMAN- As I said before, I don't like her ballads. And I've really never liked this song. It's stupid. (1/5)  <br /> <br />I'VE JUST BEGUN (HAVING MY FUN) and DO SOMETHIN'- Neither one is that great. Both could be qualified as filler. Generic electrofunk beats, yet again reminiscent of the 'new' Britney. She should really stick to pop. That's all she can do. (Score for both): (1/5)  <br /> <br />OVERALL SCORE: 57/85  <br /> <br />There are a few hits I'm not too impressed with dragging down the score, but the good ones are REALLY good, and make this ultimately a worthwhile buy. A must-have for Britney fanatics, and this is THE CD to get if you're a casual fan, because it's Britney at her very best-free of the other albums' filler. All of my favorite songs by her are here, but I have to admit I'm surprised \\"Born To Make You Happy,\\" \\"From The Bottom Of My Broken Heart,\\" \\"Don't Let Me Be The Last To Know,\\" and \\"I Love Rock 'N' Roll\\" are missing. I'm not too thrilled with any of them (\\"From The Bottom Of My Broken Heart\\" is atrocious, quite possibly her worst song ever), but they were bigger hits than some of the other tracks here. And I'm upset that the original version of \\"Overprotected\\" wasn't included. But even without those, this is a great CD with great music, and these are indeed Britney's Greatest Hits.    <br /> <br />
B000286RKW|5.0|\\"Goodfellas\\" is one of those movies I patiently waited for to get a special edition. There were many times I was close to buying the crappy, bare-bones version that was out in stores, but I never gave in. And now I am glad I didn't. <br /> <br />\\"Goodfellas\\" is the story of Henry Hill. If you don't know by now, Hill used to work for the mafia. He then ratted out his friends and went into the witness protection program. This movie is his story from his days as a kid up 'till his last days as a gangster. I think the story is very engaging and it's amazing to see how these people live their lives on a daily basis. <br /> <br />I just love watching this movie. It's as simple as that. It's got so many scenes that I can recite to my friends. It's a funny movie. It's got action. I mean if I was going to conjure the perfect mob movie in my head, this is what I would've ended up with. And when I say best \\"mob movie\\" ever made, I am not really comparing this to \\"The Godfather\\", as I think they are two completely different types of movies. <br /> <br />Ray Liotta is brilliant here as Henry Hill. Liotta wasn't a big name at the time of this movie, but he was the perfect choice. And do I even have to mention that Robert DeNiro was fantastic? He plays the character of Jimmy Conway perfectly. Although Liotta & DeNiro were great, Joe Pesci is the one who steals the show here. Pesci plays the crazy, psychotic, out of control (but hilarious) mobster. He has most of the funny lines in the movie, and his character just eats up every scene he is in. No matter who he is acting with. Paul Sorvino plays the boss named \\"Paulie\\". He hardly ever speaks in the movie, but Sorvino did that intentionally. He is so good of an actor, just his looks and glares reflect what he is trying to say. Lorraine Bracco plays Henry Hill's wife and you can definately see why they picked her for \\"The Sopranos\\". I loved her here and it was another great casting choice. <br /> <br />I remember back when I saw thismovie, I really didn't know who Martin Scorcese was. Obviously I do now, but while watching this movie you can really see what an amazing filmmaker he is. Even other popular directors today say the same thing. I hope he takes the time to give 'Raging Bull' & 'Casino' the same type of DVD treatment her gave 'Goodfellas'. Those two movies definately deserve it, as well. <br /> <br />Special Features: There are 2 seperate commentary tracks. One is with Scorcese and some of the cast & crew. The other is with Henry Hill & Edward McDonald, a former FBI agent. Both are pretty decent tracks. On disc 2, you get a very good documentary on the making of the film. Then there is a featurette interviewing other well-known directors who talk about the influence this movie had on them and their careers. Then you get a featurette talking about the \\"less than glamorous side of working for the mob\\". Finally, you get storyboard-to-screen comparisons & a trailer. Overall, this is a very good set of features. I just wish they hadn't made us wait that long for them.
6304806418|5.0|I just purchased this DVD and I remembered instantly why I enjoyed this film so much when it came out.  I would just like to answer some of the critiques listed here. <br /> <br />1)  The character of Ch was always meant to be a nemesis to Evita, but not the real character as such . In the stage production that I saw, it was a man with the typical beret and machine gun singing to the side of the action.  It would have been ridiculous and historically inaccurate to portray Ch as such in the movie version.  Ch Guevara was still a medical student when Eva died.  I think it is very effective to blend Ch into various characters because it represents the silent and not so silent opposition to the Pern Revolution.  The only time the two characters meet for real interaction is when Evita is having delusions.  The song argued in that moment perfectly clashes Ch's \\"idealism\\" with Evita's \\"realism.\\"  Ch is always there in some form, yet Evita is oblivious to his presence, brushes him off with a quick lyric or purposely chooses to ignore him.  This adds a metaphysical dimension to the plot as if Evita were increasingly self-justifying her growing power as a simple tool to help the impoverished.  <br />  <br />2)  The soundtrack to the movie is not an operatic stage version but the songs are presented using the operatic techniques of repetition.  This was done on purpose, not due to a lack of creativity.   <br /> <br />3)  When I saw this off off broadway, the people that were with me were straining to understand the singing beside the fact that they had no idea about the history of post WWII Argentina.  I don't think they enjoyed it as much as they wanted to let on.   <br /> <br />4)  Madonna sings very well and is completely understood.  I had the argument with some friends that heard the soundtrack and thought she was singing off key on the last couple of tracks...  Ummm.  Not really.  She was about ready to pass away in those scenes which in the movie are close-ups.It would have been ridiculous to have anyone belt out the lyrics in such an intimate moment before passing on.  It sounds like she is dying, because she is...   <br /> <br />5)  The cinematography is simply amazing.  The funeral scene at the very beginning was incredible as well as the scene where Eva puts her foundation to work.  Pictures of the real Evita meeting the Pope and others perfectly match the costumes used in the movie. <br /> <br />6)  For me, the main focus of the movie is the strategy of propaganda and how it can dominate reason.  The mystery lies in how much of the persuasion was authentically from the heart of the Perns and how much of it was naked manipulation.  The movie captures both aspects and yet leaves them unanswered...Much like the historical analysis of Eva Pern. <br /> <br />This movie is an awesome production ...

B0002SROT0|5.0|Take all of Elliott's albums, from Roman Candle through Figure 8 and even some Heatmiser, weave them together, and you get From a Basement on the Hill.  The songs here sting with the pain of Elliott's early 4-track work and resonate with the openness of his later studio explorations, often within a single tune such as Twilight.  Every song is genius - Elliott had few peers in song-writing talent - but one in particular wrenches my heart.  If you've ever backslid, if you've ever returned to that lover or drug one last time, you'll identify with Fond Farewell: \\"This is not my life/it's just a fond farewell to a friend\\".  Sung over a resolute strum (think Sister Golden Hair by America), Elliott's turns of phrase - e.g. \\"dying man in a living room\\" - are piercing.  Overall the record is a lovely ride, with captivating shifts from soft (Last Hour) to raucous (Shooting Star) interspersed with mesmerizing segues and sound snippets; the dynamic track sequencing reminds me of old Guided by Voices work.  Other influences are clearly John Lennon, Nick Drake, and - whoa - I even sense some Bright Eyes seeping in.  This is an album to cherish and ponder; it is wistful, powerful, and alive.

B000002IZ4|5.0|People go on about the brilliance of 'Interstate Love Song' and 'Big Empty', the two biggest hits from the album. Many of the listeners are, lets be polite, not fully aware of this album's appeal...and fail to see beyond the obvious. Don't listen to these people. Don't get me wrong I like the smash hits from Purple, but there are far greater things if you JUST LISTEN.<br /><br />Meatplow instantly brings back memories of Core, I can just imagine the hippie student, massive Core fan, sticking in Purple and hearing the first few chords, 'whoa cool man'. Meatplow is nonetheless a good song with a very catchy hook, despite being a little too derivative. Unfortunately for our hippie friend he gets bombarred with some of the most melancholy, psychedelic and ultimately disturbing music to come out of the 90s. But hell, he doesn't know it.<br /><br />Lounge Fly is an excellent song- slow and brooding with visceral lyrics. Something the hippie will relish from this totally un-Core-ish album. Still Remains is the best song STP ever created, and one of my favourite songs of the genre. It's deceivingly dark, and portrays a difficult drug surfacing for Weiland with lyrics such as - 'If you should die first, ask if you could bring a friend' - Of course our generic American no-brainer (no digs honestly) won't pick up subtlety.<br /><br />The closer, Kitchenware & Candybars, not the hidden Led Zep cover that stinks, sums up Purple. K & C is a classic, it's just a fine, miserable, gloomy and depressive closer, leaving a dark and bitter taste in the mouth. But all in a good way.<br /><br />There are real psycho songs on here, such as Vaseline and Unglued which reflect the good side of drugs - the getting high bit. These songs are undoubtedly psychedelic, acting as nice contrasts to the rest of the serious tone.<br /><br />Purple is, on a whole, a very deep and moving album. Obviously influenced by drug addictions and the up/down life that entails.
B0000WN0VY|5.0|this cd is magnificent.. in fact just about any song this man recorded is brilliant. People complain about the underproduction and siplicity of the album, but if those are your comments on the album then obviously you misunderstood thats what mr. rice was going for.. the story behind damien rice is like a fairy tale, his wishes not to exploit his cd is apparent in the cds lack in over production and stripped down sound... each song has its own sort of story behind it and my favorite would have to be cheers darlin. The story behind this song is Damien was at a bar flirting with a woman all evening and at the end of the evening she simply calls her boyfriend.. after getting home drunk damien sets up his microphone and records just about all of the song in a couple hours making most up as he goes along, from the vocals, to the chords, to the clanking of the glasses in the backround, and delivered a masterpiece. You can even tell in the singers voice he is yet to sober up. Mr. Rice's voice is very sincere and sometimes shows hints of his irish accent. The reviewers who criticized his voice must be out of his mind, i dont know what kind of voice they expect to go along with this great emotional music. he sometimes gets off the beat of his guitar to complete his thoughts but why should he not? just because this isnt an artist thats willing to take out his own creativity to make something radio friendly does not make him any less of an artist. <br />in his next album damien plans to implement the full band he travels with and make a louder sounding cd, i personally liked the softer acoutic side but as apparent on rare tracks like woman like a man, damien can make some electric gems too. <br /> <br />the dvd is worthwile if your a damien rice fan, if you dont like him as much then obviosly buy the cd without the dvd to save yourself from complaining. 0671027387|2.0|This book is a thriller/conspiracy book that involves NASA and a mysterious meteorite in Greenland.  It has a relatively good story, however if you have a problem with plot holes, this is a book to steer clear of.  If you don't know much about or don't care about the way the US government and military works, this book won't be bad.  Several things that are key to the plot, and several that aren't, detract from the author's work.  For one, the basis of the entire book is shock and frustration that NASA is spending $15 billion a year.  Unfortunately, this is a miniscule portion of the government's budget, and shouldn't shock anyone.  Then there are the myriad of improbable to impossible technologies, along with minor details that make it apparent the author didn't quite research everything he should of.  Overall, its a good story with lots of little details that really get in the way.

The #1 \\"song of all time\\" \\"Stairway To Heaven\\" which radio stations created a feeling of sickness when people heard it for the millionth time.  <br />I stayed away from listening to the entire album for 15 years and changing the radio station when I heard the first 3 notes of \\"Stairway\\", I gave in after picking up \\"BBC Sessions\\", \\"How The West Was Won\\" and the DVD, all of which I recommend to all the \\"haters\\".  <br /> <br />So with a fresh ear, here's how I felt about hearing it.  <br /> <br /> <br />Black Dog. A great opening song, it has a bluesy, classic Page riff, Plant's vocals are at its peak. Has a good groove to it.    <br /> <br />Rock and Roll. Bonham's cymbal bashing opens the song and the band kicks it into high gear. Every garage band should know this one.    <br /> <br />The Battle of Evermore. Some people think it's Robert Plant singing those high vocals. The late Sandy Denny of Fairport Convention (a band which also features the amazing Richard Thompson) sings a duet with Robert. If you haven't picked up FC's \\"Halfbricking\\", you really should, as well as Roy Harper's CD (most of British rock royalty have been on Harper's albums, including Page). Led Zep opened me up to British folk-rock from this same time period....some amazing songs from that era.  <br /> <br />Stairway to Heaven. The song is a classic because of its structure, from light to shade in one shot. The words are nonsense, but as Robert would say, \\"It's a song of hope\\". A road to enlightenment is a better way to describe it.  <br /> <br />Misty Mountain Hop: The words are somewhat dated. Their \\"hippiest\\" song. To me it's classic Bonham/Plant with a sound that you'd hear more on \\"Houses of the Holy\\".   <br />  <br />Going to California: Plant and Page LOVED Joni Mitchell (pick up Blue and prove if I'm wrong), and wrote the song for her. It's one that comes off nicely live, both back then and in 94. A nice song overall.  <br /> <br />When the Levee Breaks: Classic Bonham. An old Memphis Minnie cover done the Zep way. B00065VTU4|5.0|This album brings back memories. I remember first hearing \\"I shot the sheriff\\" in a bar and immediately thinking that EC had \\"sold out\\" by moving beyond his 'guitar hero\\" image. How wrong I was!! This is a great album that easily has worn the test of time. The band is arguably Clapton's best of his solo units (and there IS plenty of great guitar work). It is, in a way, a cross between the D&TD album and his first solo effort. During ECs tenure in Blind Faith, he became passionately interested in the music of the Band. This influence is evident here in the ensemble playing, shared vocal chores, economical guitar playing and the deadened drum sounds. However, ECs strong musical personality makes the album his own. Great original songwriting and an excellent choice of covers. The live material is a wonderful treat. It is great to hear those renditions finally on a legit release. For those of you interested, THIS IS WHERE CLAPTON'S SOLO CAREER REALLY BEGINS TO COOK. Long may he live!!!!

B0002IVN9W|5.0|It's always sad when a group of people, bound by emotion, family, love and a shared musical vision, are so cruely taken from us by an uncaring and indifferent world. It's doubly sad when such a group were responsible for one of the loveliest, most under-rated albums of 2004. The Funeral will sadly have to be their epitaph and last will and testament. These songs will remain a glorious summation of that ineffable quality of life lived on the crest of a crashing wave, when a moment's perfection is backlit by its impending end. The band's influences were carefully integrated into the textures of their songs and pointed to such disparate sources as Bowie, 80s synth pop, the Pixies and Decline of British Sea Power, poured over with French Canadian imagery and song. We could've hoped for a glorious career for this band. Sadly, it wasn't to be. They came from nowhere, flowered for a day ... and vanished. All we have left to console ourselves with is the humdrum reality of manufactured pop rock, insipid chart-aspiring talentless Madonna-wannabe popstar hackettes, and Justin Timberlake.

B00005JMUL|5.0|I went to see this movie tonight with a mentally handicapped friend - \\"Michael\\" -- (from a L'Arche home here in Winnipeg, Canada).  We were the first persons in the theatre for the very first evening showing in this city - and we were the last to leave.  We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves - enchanted by the movie's subtleties and happily exhausted by its roller-coaster rides.<br /><br />Time and again, Michael (who is sensitive, compassionate and with a good sense of humor) turned to me in the darkness, smiling in appreciation at the exact same moments I turned to see his reactions. Each time this happened, it was at a moment in the film when some little detail, perfectly captured through superb 'cinematography,' brought moisture to my normally cynical eye, and a warm smile to Michael's innocent face.<br /><br />Some examples:  There is a lone, black child on this apparent 'dream train' to the North Pole - a girl of about ten or eleven years, and like a painting come to life, the miraculous technology at work in this film  captures the particular sensibilities of this  compassionate, black youngster ---  We see small mannerisms of someone comfortable with herself in a way the other (ten or so) white kids on the train are not.  And the effect is profound --- the movie audience, including some children of that same age group, went silent at such moments in the film.<br /><br />My friend Michael - who has a 'savant' genius for perceiving my emotions, and expressing them for me out loud in public --- Michael turned to me with a delighted smile when the girl on the train reaches out to hold the hands of the poorest boy, sitting alone in the rear compartment; and later, she hugs two other boys, (one of them the central character) --- at their final parting. At that moment I held up a finger to my lips to try to hush Michael, but couldn't prevent him from saying aloud:  \\"She's such a sweetheart.\\"  There were murmurs of appreciation in the darkness around us, responding to this innocent sentiment.<br /><br />There is a sublime moment, on the back platform of the moving train -- the Northern Lights glimmering in the distance -- when the young girl joins in song with the poorest kid on the train (a younger boy from a dilapidated home on the \\"far side of the tracks\\"). I admit to being overcome with emotion during this duet (a lovely, strong melody with poignant lyrics) - and I blurted out loud to Michael, after the first chorus: \\"What a wonderful song!\\"  The refrain includes the words \\"When Christmas comes to town.\\"  [It's a song so good that, with some future 'cover versions' by serious musicians who could do it justice ---  this \\"Christmas Comes to Town\\" song could, I believe, deservedly join the small list of true, Christmas 'classics.']<br /><br />I'd have to agree with anyone who thinks this movie is a little short on plot.  And yet . . .  once you've suspended disbelief --  beginning with an earth-shattering, Christmas-eve arrival of a steam-puffing, passenger train on a small-town Michigan street, directly outside the home of the movie's central character -- once we've swallowed that premise, the movie disarmingly embraces the child in us, (including our fears) and our reservations vanish without our noticing.<br /><br />Just as great `realistic' painters, (think Rembrandt or Vermeer) worked wonders of light & shadow that no mere photograph could ever capture, so too this computer-animated marvel takes your breath away through an accumulation of tiny but acute observations that could never be captured by conventional cinematography. Prime examples from the opening scenes:<br /><br />A shaft of light illuminates the boy's bedroom, and he is reflected in a chrome, automobile hubcap leaning against a wall; at once we share his view -- through the keyhole of his bedroom door - we can see only the backs and the dressing gowns of mother and father, as they say goodnight to the boy's young sister, after determining the state of her belief in Santa's existence - a belief no longer shared by the older brother, whose eye is at the keyhole.<br /><br />Later, on the train, there's an exquisite close up of the boy's face, a slight blemish above the pores on his upper right cheek; the `camera' pans in rotation, capturing perfectly, the texture of the boy's hair, and that of the young black girl sitting beside him  -- subtleties of such perfection one wonders if the unique, artistic accomplishment of \\"Polar Express\\" could ever be surpassed.<br /><br />The film's last scene, consists entirely of a close-up view of a small, silver bell (of the type associated with sleigh rides) with its attached 'ribbon' of red leather.  The little bell helps make the final point about `Belief' --- in things unseen, (or forgotten, and thus inaccessible to some adults). So simple, so powerful, so enlightening an image. My friend Michael turned to me at that moment, with a radiant smile. And we just shook our heads in awe.<br /><br />----<br /><br />Yes, this movie must have SOME shortcomings - one or two moments that don't quite work as intended by the creators.  But right now, in the afterglow, I can't recall what they were. The film  was just too satisfying an experience!<br /><br />I'm a 57-year-old grandfather who happens to believe that \\"The Polar Express\\" is the first, true Christmas classic in almost 60 years.  Not since the original Kris Kringle \\"Miracle\\" movie of 1947, has any film (to my jaded eye) so transcended our secular, commercial views of the Holiday Season, with such uplifting and fresh reminders of the timeless and true spirit of Christmas.<br /><br />Mark Blackburn<br /><br />Winnipeg Canada.e of her belief in Santa's existence - a belief no longer shared by the older brother, whose eye is at the keyhole.  <br /> <br />Later, on the train, there's an exquisite close up of the boy's face, a slight blemish above the pores on his upper right cheek; the `camera' pans in rotation, capturing perfectly, the texture of the boy's hair, and that of the young black girl sitting beside him  -- subtleties of such perfection one wonders if the unique, artistic accomplishment of \\"Polar Express\\" could ever be surpassed.   <br /> <br />The film's last scene, consists entirely of a close-up view of a small, silver bell (of the type associated with sleigh rides) with its attached 'ribbon' of red leather.  The little bell helps make the final point about `Belief' --- in things unseen, (or forgotten, and thus inaccessible to some adults). So simple, so powerful, so enlightening an image. My friend Michael turned to me at that moment, with a radiant smile. And we just shook our heads in awe.   <br /> <br />---- <br /> <br />Yes, this movie must have SOME shortcomings - one or two moments that don't quite work as intended by the creators.  But right now, in the afterglow, I can't recall what they were. The film  was just too satisfying an experience!  <br /> <br />I'm a 57-year-old grandfather who happens to believe that \\"The Polar Express\\" is the first, true Christmas classic in almost 60 years.  Not since the original Kris Kringle \\"Miracle\\" movie of 1947, has any film (to my jaded eye) so transcended our secular, commercial views of the Holiday Season, with such uplifting and fresh reminders of the timeless and true spirit of Christmas.  <br /> <br />Mark Blackburn <br />Winnipeg Canada.

0679879269|4.0|(...)    These are books aimed at children and written in that vein. The heroine is a 12 year old girl (verging on 13). The books are couched in the fantastic and the allegorical. However, that is not to say that Pullman does not take his readers seriously. He is absolutely unflinching in his portrayals-including those involving violence and disappointment. These are the ways in which they begin to appeal not just to children (who so desperately crave to be taken seriously) but to adults as well. These books have enjoyed some astonishing success and they are well-deserved. Their influence on the genre will be in their presence-we don't think that many authors will attempt to imitate Pullman because they will be too timid to do so. He cannot be matched for how brutally honest he can be with the youth. It will be interesting to see how His Dark Materials will survive the test of time but because they are so antithetical to so many deeply entrenched \\"traditional values\\" we think that they begin to suffer a swift decline in future generations as the fear Pullman engenders in other authors will also be felt by parents when recommending books to their children.     WHO SHOULD READ THIS:    A difficult question to put to these books! Indeed, who should read them? Precocious and intelligent children should be introduced to His Dark Materials for they teach and celebrate simultaneously imagination, history, engineering, and physics. For many young readers, these books may be the first that seriously challenge their notions of justice, faith, and adulthood. There is such a great deal to admire about these books and parents trying to suppress them may in fact spur children in to reading them with greater furor. For wit, plot, and technique Pullman is certainly a match for anything Rowlings is doing (if not her equal in reaching larger audiences).     WHO SHOULD PASS:    Very conservative religious parents will be appalled by the last half of the trilogy. In fact, religious adults who read these books often complain of how profoundly annoyed and attacked they feel. Considered and educated readers will sense what we mean when we say Pullman's arguments become a bit facile by the end. Really, it's too bad--though how it could be avoided, we don't know--that His Dar Materials tackles the notions of faith in the way they do because in all respects they are very finely crafted and well-worth the time to read.     (...)
068987474X|2.0|When I initially read this book (the very day it was released in the bookstore), I was excited and thrilled.  \\"Finally!\\" I thought.  \\"A book teaching a different perspective!  Something that doesn't focus on playing games or being a b****.\\"  But after watching the Oprah show featuring the authors, I was very disturbed.  The man who explained his four tiers of women to the audience, Is he is supposed to be a typical representative of the male species?  It IS possible that woman in the fourth teir is aware of what her relationship is with him, and if they are both okay with that - it doesn't make either one of them a jerk or a player.  And what about the poor girl who told Greg that she was having a problem getting her boyfriend of 2.5 years to marry her?  Greg's response was \\"I'm sorry.  He's just not that into you.\\"  and then she began to cry.  Okay, so I'm a softy for that and my heart melted.  But really?  Is this what dating is about?  Whether or not a guy is into me?  Am I supposed to be the passive little female accepting dates from male prospects and waiting around always hoping if he's into me?  How about deciding whether or not I'm into him?  The big part of dating or any type of relationship is about boundaries!  We all have hang-ups, fears, emotional problems, etc.  Being successful in dating is all a matter of having good boundaries and knowing what you want, what sorts of behavior you will accept, where you draw the lines, etc and a having a little confidence in yourself doesn't hurt.  And maybe some of us do need a book to tell us if a guy is calling us at 2AM and asking to have sex with us and nothing else, then yeah, he isn't interested in having a relationship with me or if he says \\"I don't want a relationship\\" then that's what he means.  But I don't need a book telling me that every guy I date who isn't dying to marry me like a dog in heat, isn't that into me and I should just move on.  Relationships are work.  People are not that simple.  This bookis just another \\"Get Confidence Quick\\" scheme that teaches women some techniques that appear to the eye of the beholder that she is confident and has good boundaries with people.  As for this book, I'm \\"just not that into you.\\"
B0000DJZA5|4.0|I remember a certain magazine had the Beatles on the cover saying \\"Lost Beatles tapes discovered.\\"  Much of the lost tapes were during the Get Back/Let It Be sessions.  Finally, the \\"new\\" release Let It Be... Naked comes out.  Is it an improvement over the original release back in 1970?  Yes and no (I gave the original release 4 stars when I reviewed it).      I prefer this version of \\"The Long and Winding Road\\" with Billy Preston's organ solo over the Spectorized version (I know I'm going to get some disagreements here for this opinion).  I also like this version of \\"I Me Mine\\" but it isn't exactly \\"naked\\" since the middle 8th and final verse are tacked on to keep the song over 1 minute (as many of you know, this was the last song the Beatles recorded together as an \\"existing\\" unit, sans John, back in 1970).  Also, this version of \\"Across the Universe\\" is an improvement over the muddy sounding version on the original release (and even an improvement over the version with the chirping birds) but it doesn't sound too different over the version on Anthology 2 (this song was recorded in early 1968).  Also, \\"Don't Let Me Down,\\" the B side to \\"Get Back,\\" is included.  What's missing is John's wisecracks at the beginning of \\"Two of Us\\" and the end of \\"Get Back.\\"  \\"I hope we passed the audition\\" is a worthy way of ending that song.  Also, it would've been nice if the song \\"Dig It\\" were a few minutes longer and included (I read the original version was about 12 minutes long but that would be a little too much even for me!).  The remaining songs (save \\"Let It Be\\" which has George Martin's orchestra in the background swiped) don't sound too different from the original release, except that the mix is a little cleaner.  Also, the order of the songs threw me off a little bit, making it sound more like Scenes from the Let It Be Sessions.  4 stars    Now for the Fly on the Wall disk.  It's interesting, but probably not something you'll want to hear over and over again.  There areexcerpts of songs like \\"All Things Must Pass,\\" \\"Child of Nature\\" (which would later become \\"Jealous Guy\\"), \\"Taking a Trip to Carolina\\" written and sung by Ringo, a piano piece by Paul, \\"Every Little Thing\\" and \\"Sun King.\\"  It also includes dialogue from the sessions by all 4 Beatles (there's a bit of it in the booklet, too).  3 and 1/2 stars    I was hoping they'd include what would've been the Get Back (with Let It Be and 10 Others album, but I guess Paul, Ringo and Glyn Johns didn't consider that worthy of release.  Paul had said in the liner notes for LIB...N: \\"If we had today's technology then, [Let It Be] would sound like this because that was the noise we made in the studio.\\"  That's a nice thing for Paul to say but John and George are no longer around to agree or disagree (though George reportedly did approve of this newer project before his passing away).  I'd like to see the movie Let It Be re-released.  It's a great movie, but depressing, because it shows how and why one of the greatest rock bands of all time split up.  One reviewer has said it's in the planning, let's keep our fingers crossed.

This DVD picks up on that \\"performer to audience\\" interaction. These new versions are just beautiful and Gilmour's guitar work is amazing. There are some nice guest appearances such as Richard Wright as he performs \\"Breakthrough\\", a song from his solo album. It's a great song, and if you listen closely you will hear a familiar tune or two as it comes to an end (\\"home, home again\\").
